title: Goldman ex-CEO Blankfein: Tariffs may hurt the US, but China loses more
text: The United States may be feeling the pain of tariffs now, but they will hurt China in the longer term, says former Goldman Sachs CEO Lloyd Blankfein.

title: Stocks gain back some ground as investors assess the trade war’s impact
text: Stocks had their best trading day in a while on Tuesday as investors took a break from selling to assess the actual effects of the trade war with China. Both the Dow Jones Industrial Average and the S&P 500 gained back some of their losses with the DJIA climbing 207.06 points to close at 25,532.05 […]

title: Luckin IPO To Pit Chinese Coffee Unicorn Startup Vs. Starbucks Mermaid
text: Luckin Coffee — the express coffee chain looking to take on Starbucks in China — is set to begin trading on Friday.

title: What Investors Should Know as the Trade War Escalates
text: Here's why trade tensions are causing market turbulence and what investors need to keep in mind.

title: Wall Street Seems To Relax A Bit As Trade Talks Expected To Continue
text: The mood this morning seems a bit lighter as the U.S. and China are expected to continue trade talks.

title: Wall Street poised for gains after Monday's heavy selloff
text: U.S. stock index futures indicated gains at the open on Tuesday, as optimistic comments from Washington and Beijing took the edge off market concerns about a further escalation in trade war.

title: Oil prices jump on drone attack on Saudi Aramco facilities
text: Oil prices rose sharply on Tuesday after top exporter Saudi Arabia said explosive-laden drones launched by a Yemeni armed movement aligned to Iran had attacked facilities belonging to state oil company Aramco.

title: Hemptown USA Completes $17.8M Financing Round
text: Hemptown Organics Corp., a hemp company that does business as Hemptown USA, said Tuesday it raised CA$24 million ($17.81 million) to fund an expansion of its operations.

title: India's Jet Airways CEO Dube resigns
text: Embattled Indian carrier Jet Airways said on Tuesday Chief Executive Officer Vinay Dube had resigned with immediate effect.

title: Cargill invests in company that grows meat using 3D engineering
text: Cargill announced Tuesday that it's investing in Aleph Farms, which grows meat from beef cells using 3D tissue engineering. The company demonstrated in December 2018 that it could grow a steak from cells.

title: Oil prices jump as Saudi energy minister reports drone 'terrorism' against pipeline infrastructure
text: Oil prices rose sharply Tuesday morning on reports of a drone attack at oil pumping stations in Saudi Arabia.

title: How $400 Billion Volatility-Target Funds Will Worsen Stock Selloff
text: An uptick in stock market turbulence threatens to disrupt an investing strategy that depends on market stability.

title: EV startup Rimac scores $90M investment from Hyundai and Kia
text: Rimac Automobili, the European EV startup that landed an investment from Porsche last year, has again gained the backing of traditional automakers after Hyundai Motor Company and Kia Motors jointly invested €80 million, or around $90 million. Beyond the significant cash infusion, the three parties said the deal includes “a strategic partnership to collaborate on […]

title: India’s largest mobile wallet company Paytm now offers a credit card
text: Paytm, India’s largest mobile wallet app, has branched out to several businesses in recent years. On Tuesday, it added another category to the list: credit cards.

title: Huawei is not controlled by China, executive says
text: Huawei is a private company that is not controlled by the Chinese government and would refuse to hand over information to Beijing although no such request has been made, the firm's Vice President of Western Europe said on Tuesday.

title: What Is Oroco Stock Worth Right Now?
text: Oroco's management will not tell you that the stock can be worth $17 per share because they always low-ball.

title: Members only: U.S. retailers revamp loyalty schemes for Amazon era
text: With private fitting rooms, members-only stores and clever apps, U.S. department stores are reinventing their old and tested loyalty programs to fend off the challenge from e-commerce giant Amazon.com Inc and other online rivals.
